Harvey Lyman Company

Walnut Grove Facility



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.    FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Harvey Lyman Company, A Division of The Lyman Group, Inc. (Lyman or TLG), Walnut Grove Facility (Facility) at 14301 Railroad Avenue, Walnut Grove, California 95690 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response / Contingency Plan has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

2.    FACILITY INFORMATION

??    The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Delta Area of Northern California.

??    Anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients. 

??    Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 14,323-gallon storage tank (bullet) at the site.  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 62,580 pounds.

??    Aqua ammonia is received by truck and stored in two 20,500-gallon, above-ground tanks at the site.  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 

311,600 pounds. 

3.    THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes.

4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

Safety Information:  Lyman ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for r

eview by employees.  The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on 

November 24, 2015.

Hazard Review:  A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes.  The most recent update of the hazard review was conducted on June 16, 2015.  Results indicate that no high risk hazards were identified through the hazard review update.

Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed.  The operating procedures were last revised in November 2015.  Operating procedures for the Anhydrous Ammonia Process are certified annually, with the last annual certification on April 7, 2015.

Training:  The Facility staff, as well as TLG corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff.  A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.  The current training program is comprised of the following:

??    Initial employee training;

??    Periodic refresher training;

??    Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification;

??    Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and

??    Training records for each employee.

Maintenance:  The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release.  The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training.  The latest equipment inspection was conducted on 

November 23, 2015, and the latest review of maintenance procedures was conducted on

November 20, 2015.

RMP Change Management:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues

must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health.  The Facility RMP Change Management (RMPCM) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures.

Pre-startup Review:  The pre-startup review applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated.  Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre-startup safety review.  This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the RMPCM review.  Additionally, a pre-startup safety review is performed in conjunction with the RMPCM review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety information.  

Compliance Audits:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years.  Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted in March 2013. 

Incident Investigation:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place.  The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations.  The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.

Hot Work Permit:  Hot work does not typically occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process.  However,

should hot work be required, Lyman has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements.

Contractor Safety:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Walnut Grove Facility.  The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia.  

In addition to the prevention program elements described above, the following chemical-specific prevention steps have been implemented.

Anhydrous Ammonia and Aqua Ammonia:  The Facility implements the provisions of the "Safety Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc.; California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Subchapter 1, "Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders"; and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia."

5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.

6.    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements.  A Consolidated Emergency Response / Contingency Plan has been prepared, was most recently updated on September 15, 2015, and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.

7.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility.  Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintena
nce of safe conditions.  Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.
